title: Prepare the environment
text: using ZonationR, must install Zonation 5 software computer. Visit Zonation 5 project site: zonationteam.github.io Download appropriate installer executable operating system (e.g., Windows installer, Linux AppImage). Install unpack software, note installation path — ’ll use later calling Zonation R.

title: Prepare the environment
text: install ZonationR GitHub (development version): Load package:
code: if (!require(devtools)) install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("thiago-cav/ZonationR") library(ZonationR)

title: Prepare the environment
text: running full analysis, ’s good practice verify R can find Zonation 5 executable. successful, function confirm path points correct Zonation binary.
code: # Check that the executable is valid check_zonation_executable()

title: Prepare the environment
text: Zonation analyses require input feature layers (e.g., species distribution rasters) share extent, resolution, alignment. ZonationR includes helper function check whether layers harmonized. function reports layers differ extent, resolution, alignment, helping identify mismatches running Zonation avoiding potential errors.
code: # Example feature files (placeholders)  # Check harmonization status of feature layers

title: Prepare the environment
text: installation checks done, ’re ready : prepare Zonation input files using create_feature_list() create_settings_file(), generate executable call create_zonation5_call(), run prioritization run_zonation5(). can explore subsequent vignettes focused workflow examples.

title: Prepare the environment
text: ’re new spatial conservation prioritization, check resources: Zonation 5 manual — detailed instructions explanations prioritization settings. (zonationteam.github.io)

title: Why spatial conservation prioritization?
text: Spatial conservation decisions ultimately decisions act. Even conservation goals global, real impact happens specific places, whether ’s forest, coral reef, river basin, broader landscape. space finite, conservation always involves making choices. Protecting one area usually means protecting another, least immediately extent. simple yet crucial reality shapes modern conservation planning: Biodiversity unevenly distributed across globe. Threats vary spatially, affecting areas others. Resources limited, creating competition among different land uses priorities. Therefore, conservation operates constraints : Limited budgets, Conflicting land uses, Multiple objectives maximized simultaneously. constraints failures, starting point effective, strategic conservation planning.

what: From Spatial Patterns to Decision Challenges
title: Why spatial conservation prioritization?
text: past decades, conservation science made enormous progress data availability. Species distribution models, habitat maps, remote sensing products, global biodiversity databases now accessible ever. However, conservation planners often challenged lack data, difficulty turning complex, sometimes incomplete data clear decisions. common first approach layer maps top one another: visualizing species richness, threat levels, habitat extent. informative, rarely leads clear choices. multiple features considered simultaneously, conflicts emerge: Areas important one species may less important another. Regions high biodiversity value may overlap areas intense human use. often leads familiar frustration: “information need — deciding still hard?” problem lies data alone, lack structured way resolve trade-offs across space.

what: Moving Beyond Yes or No: The Need to Prioritize
title: Why spatial conservation prioritization?
text: Many conservation decisions often seen simple binary choices: protect protect, include exclude. reality, conservation planning rarely works way. Decisions usually incremental — actions happen time, budgets change, priorities evolve new information becomes available. dynamic context, flexibility key. Instead asking “area protected?” planners often need ask: areas matter ? actions happen first? part landscape can addressed now, start? shift selection prioritization fundamentally changes problem.goal longer find single “best” solution, support informed decisions work uncertainty constraints. Understanding shift helps planners make smarter choices adapt real-world challenges.

what: The need to prioritize, not just select
title: Why spatial conservation prioritization?
text: Many conservation decisions framed binary choices: protect protect, include exclude. reality, conservation planning rarely works way. Decisions typically incremental. Actions taken time, budgets change, priorities revised new information becomes available. context, flexibility matters. Rather asking whether area protected , planners often need ask areas matter , actions happen first. part landscape can addressed short term, locations receive priority? shift—selection prioritization—changes nature problem. goal longer define single optimal solution, support informed choices uncertainty constraint.

title: Why spatial conservation prioritization?
text: Spatial conservation prioritization addresses challenge ordering locations according relative importance biodiversity conservation. Instead dividing space protected unprotected areas, produces ranking reflects much location contributes overall conservation goals. ordering inherently comparative. importance given place depends complements places, many features supports, irreplaceable within broader landscape. ranked solution allows decision-makers explore different levels conservation action, adjust boundaries, evaluate trade-offs transparently. stage, algorithms technical details required understand idea. matters conceptual shift: conservation planning becomes process ordering space importance, rather drawing fixed lines map.

title: Why spatial conservation prioritization?
text: problem fully built, Zonation introduced naturally. Explain : • Zonation produces spatial ranking conservation importance • integrates multiple biodiversity features • supports transparent reproducible decision-making point, curiosity earned — forced.

title: Why spatial conservation prioritization?
text: section grounds expectations. Clarify ZonationR: • replace Zonation • helps structure run analyses R • designed learning, teaching, reproducible workflows sets transition practical work.

title: Why spatial conservation prioritization?
text: Zonation external software. Cover: • installation means practice • Platform differences (Windows vs Linux) • installation separate package commands yet — just orientation.

title: Why spatial conservation prioritization?
text: Introduce validation best practice. Explain: • checking executable matters • Common configuration issues Introduce: • check_zonation_executable() Conceptual + light practical framing.

title: Why spatial conservation prioritization?
text: Close often-ignored critical step. Explain: • spatial alignment matters • Resolution, extent, projection issues • errors propagate silently Introduce: • feature harmonization checks
code: library()

title: Authors and Citation
text: Thiago Cavalcante. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Cavalcante T (2026). ZonationR: toolkit integrating executing Zonation 5 software directly R. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://github.com/thiago-cav/ZonationR.
code: @Manual{,   title = {ZonationR: A toolkit for integrating and executing Zonation 5 software directly from R},   author = {Thiago Cavalcante},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://github.com/thiago-cav/ZonationR}, }

what: A toolkit for integrating and executing Zonation 5 software directly from R
title: A toolkit for integrating and executing Zonation 5 software directly from R
text: ZonationR R package provides interface easily integrate execute Zonation 5 software directly R. package developed support teaching learning, making easier R users get started Zonation 5 learn spatial prioritization techniques. also facilitates efficient spatial prioritization workflows, improving reproducibility automation.

title: A toolkit for integrating and executing Zonation 5 software directly from R
text: can install development version ZonationR GitHub :
code: if (!require(devtools)) install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("thiago-cav/ZonationR")

title: A toolkit for integrating and executing Zonation 5 software directly from R
text: ZonationR interface Zonation 5, means Zonation must able read write files disk. ensure works smoothly, recommended run analysis inside R project whose directory writable. running examples , please make sure : Zonation 5 installed system know path Zonation 5 installation directory current R project directory writable input output files generated ZonationR created within current R project directory.

title: A toolkit for integrating and executing Zonation 5 software directly from R
text: basic example get setup running ZonationR. files created within current R project, biodiversity input data used provided package.
code: # Load necessary libraries library(ZonationR)

title: A toolkit for integrating and executing Zonation 5 software directly from R
text: First, copy example biodiversity data provided package local directory. raster layers used features Zonation analysis.
code: #---------------------------------------------------- # Create a folder for biodiversity input data #---------------------------------------------------- dir.create("biodiversity", showWarnings = FALSE)  extdata_path <- system.file("extdata", "biodiversity", package = "ZonationR") file.copy(list.files(extdata_path, full.names = TRUE),           "biodiversity", overwrite = TRUE)

title: A toolkit for integrating and executing Zonation 5 software directly from R
text: Next, create three compulsory input files required Zonation 5. zonation_path argument must point directory Zonation 5 installed system.
code: # Create feature list file feature_list(spp_file_dir = "biodiversity")  # Create settings file settings_file(feature_list_file = "feature_list.txt")  # Create the Zonation command file command_file(zonation_path = "C:/Program Files (x86)/Zonation5")

title: A toolkit for integrating and executing Zonation 5 software directly from R
text: Finally, run Zonation 5 analysis. outputs written project directory following standard Zonation folder structure.
code: run_command_file(".")

what: Create a Zonation command File — command_file
title: Create a Zonation command File — command_file
text: function generates command file running Zonation specifies analysis options related parameters. file saved .cmd (Windows) .sh (Linux) suffix.

title: Create a Zonation command File — command_file
code: command_file(   os = "Windows",   zonation_path,   flags = "",   marginal_loss_mode = "CAZ2",   gui_activated = TRUE,   settings_file = "settings_file.z5",   output_dir = "output" )

title: Create a Zonation command File — command_file
text: os Operating system. Default "Windows"; set "Linux" using Linux system. zonation_path specification path Zonation 5 installed. flags Flags control analysis options used. Used include single letter codes switch analysis options . Available options : , w, g, h, x, X, t. marginal_loss_mode Character string specifying marginal loss rule. Available options "CAZ1", "CAZ2", "ABF", "CAZMAX", "LOAD", "RAND". Default "CAZ2". gui_activated parameter controls whether Graphical User Interface (GUI) launched running command file. default TRUE (GUI activated). settings_file Character string specifying settings file. Default "settings_file.z5". output_dir character string specifying name output directory analysis results saved. Default "output".

title: Create a Zonation command File — command_file
text: Zonation command file containing specified analysis options.

title: Create a Zonation command File — command_file
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ command_file(   zonation_path = "C:/Program Files (x86)/Zonation5" )  command_file(   zonation_path = "C:/Program Files (x86)/Zonation5",   marginal_loss_mode = "ABF",   gui_activated = FALSE ) } # }

what: Plot coverage distribution at a given rank — coverage_distribution
title: Plot coverage distribution at a given rank — coverage_distribution
text: function reads Zonation feature curves file plots distribution feature coverage values specified priority rank. output ggplot object, can customized user. Optionally, plot can saved disk high-quality figure.

title: Plot coverage distribution at a given rank — coverage_distribution
code: coverage_distribution(   data_path,   target_rank,   save_path = NULL,   dpi = 300,   width = 8,   height = 6 )

title: Plot coverage distribution at a given rank — coverage_distribution
text: data_path Character. Path Zonation output CSV file (feature_curves.csv) containing feature curves. target_rank Numeric. rank value coverage distributions extracted plotted. save_path Character. Optional file path save plot. file format inferred specified extension (e.g. ".tiff"). dpi Numeric. Resolution (dots per inch) saved figures. Default 300. width Numeric. Width saved figure inches. Default 8. height Numeric. Height saved figure inches. Default 6.

title: Plot coverage distribution at a given rank — coverage_distribution
text: ggplot object showing distribution feature coverage values specified priority rank.

title: Plot coverage distribution at a given rank — coverage_distribution
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ p <- coverage_distribution(   data_path = "C:/path/to/feature_curves.csv",   target_rank = 0.9 )  p + ggplot2::theme_classic()  coverage_distribution(   data_path = "C:/path/to/feature_curves.csv",   target_rank = 0.9,   save_path = "coverage_histogram.png" ) } # }

what: Create a feature list from raster files — feature_list
title: Create a feature list from raster files — feature_list
text: function generates feature list raster files specified directory, adding optional attributes list based user-defined parameters. resulting feature list written text file. Supported raster formats include GeoTIFF (.tif, .tiff), ERDAS Imagine (.img), ASCII Grid (.asc).

title: Create a feature list from raster files — feature_list
code: feature_list(spp_file_dir, weight = NULL, group = NULL, threshold = NULL)

title: Create a feature list from raster files — feature_list
text: spp_file_dir character string specifying directory containing raster files. weight optional numeric vector (float) assign weights features list. group optional integer vector (int) representing output group number raster. threshold optional numeric vector (float) representing threshold values raster. thresholding applied, values input raster threshold set zero. Layers contain zeros thresholding removed analysis.

title: Create a feature list from raster files — feature_list
text: text file containing feature list rasters along additional attributes specified user.

title: Create a feature list from raster files — feature_list
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ feature_list(spp_file_dir = "path/to/raster/files") } # }

what: Run a Zonation command file — run_command_file
title: Run a Zonation command file — run_command_file
text: function runs Zonation 5 analysis directly R executing command file located specified folder. Windows, function looks single .cmd file; Linux, looks single .sh file.

title: Run a Zonation command file — run_command_file
code: run_command_file(folder)

title: Run a Zonation command file — run_command_file
text: folder character string specifying path folder containing Zonation command file.

title: Run a Zonation command file — run_command_file
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ run_command_file("C:/path/to/folder") } # }

what: Create a Settings File for a Zonation Analysis — settings_file
title: Create a Settings File for a Zonation Analysis — settings_file
text: function generates settings file various parameters related input data analysis configuration. resulting settings file saved .z5 extension can used directly Zonation software.

title: Create a Settings File for a Zonation Analysis — settings_file
code: settings_file(   feature_list_file,   external_solution_file = NULL,   analysis_area_mask_layer = NULL,   hierarchic_mask_layer = NULL,   cost_layer = NULL )

title: Create a Settings File for a Zonation Analysis — settings_file
text: feature_list_file character string specifying feature list file. compulsory parameter. external_solution_file character string specifying full path /name external solution file. analysis_area_mask_layer character string specifying full path /name analysis area mask layer file. hierarchic_mask_layer character string specifying full path /name hierarchic mask layer file. cost_layer character string specifying full path /name cost layer file.

title: Create a Settings File for a Zonation Analysis — settings_file
text: .z5 file containing specified settings.

title: Create a Settings File for a Zonation Analysis — settings_file
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ settings_file(feature_list_file = "feature_list.txt") } # }

what: Plot summary performance curves from Zonation output — summary_curves
title: Plot summary performance curves from Zonation output — summary_curves
text: function reads Zonation summary curves file plots one summary metrics priority rank. output ggplot object, can customized user. Optionally, plot can saved disk high-quality figure.

title: Plot summary performance curves from Zonation output — summary_curves
code: summary_curves(   data_path,   metrics,   facet = FALSE,   save_path = NULL,   dpi = 300,   width = 8,   height = 6 )

title: Plot summary performance curves from Zonation output — summary_curves
text: data_path Character. Path Zonation output file (summary_curves.csv). metrics Character vector. Names summary metrics plot. Metrics can overlaid share units value range. Fraction-based metrics can overlaid together, remaining_area remaining_cost overlaid metrics. facet Logical. TRUE, metrics plotted separate panels. used plotting metrics different units value ranges. Default FALSE. save_path Character. Optional file path save plot. file format inferred file extension (e.g. ".tiff"). dpi Numeric. Resolution (dots per inch) saved figures. Default 300. width Numeric. Width saved figure inches. Default 8. height Numeric. Height saved figure inches. Default 6.

title: Plot summary performance curves from Zonation output — summary_curves
text: ggplot object visualizing one Zonation summary metrics plotted priority rank.

title: Plot summary performance curves from Zonation output — summary_curves
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ ## Overlaid plot p <- summary_curves(   data_path = "path/to/summary_curves.csv",   metrics = c("mean", "max") )  p + ggplot2::theme_classic()  ## Plot area and cost in separate panels summary_curves(   data_path = "path/to/summary_curves.csv",   metrics = c("remaining_area", "remaining_cost"),   facet = TRUE ) } # }
